docs.title: lecture9 memory management
docs.text:
memory is the key component of computer in the con Neumann architecture modelall data and code is stored in memory

memory management needs to provide allocation and protection

requirements:

we have no knowledge of how memory address generated and no knowledge what memeory addresses are used for

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Basic concepts: - memory allocation - swapping: exchange between the disk and the network

VitualMemeory - paging

Demand paging - page replacement models - working set model

linux implementation

docs.title: logical/Phisical address space
docs.text:
memory management binds logical address space to physical address space

  • Logical address is generated by the CPU and seen by processes
  • Physical address is seen by the memory unit and referes to physical system memory

these are same in compile and load-time address-binding schemes

but different in executing time address-binding schemes

docs.title: memory management unit(MMU)
docs.text:
mapping logical to physical addresses

user process deals with logical address only

MMU has to be fast so it is HARDWARE

docs.title: Contiguous Memory Allocation
docs.text:
Main memory usualy split into two partitions:

  • Resident operating system(kernel), this is ususally held in low memory
  • user processes(user), this is held in high memory

contiguous allocation with relocation registers

  • base register contains value of the smallest physical address
  • limit register contains range of logical addresses, each logical address must be less than limit register
  • MMU maps logical address dynamically

so we do this

docs.title: multi-partition allocation
docs.text:
hole: - block of available memory - holes of various size scattered throughout memory

when a process arrives, allocate a hole bug enough

so it maintains information about allocated partitions and free partitions

docs.title: dynamic storage allocation
docs.text:
• first fit: allocate the first hole that is big enough
  • best fit: allocate smallest hole that is big enough, but you must search the entire list, unless ordered by size
  • worst fit: allocate largest hole, must search list and produces largest leftover hole

docs.title: fragmentation:
docs.text:
external fragmentation: you have 100MB of free memory but in 200 half a MB holes

internal fragmentation: allocated memory larger than requested memory

reduce external fragmentation by compaction

  • shuffle memory contents to place all free memory together in one large block
  • Leads to I/O bottlenecks

docs.title: Swapping
docs.text:
the problem is that the number of processes id limited by the amount of available memory, but only the running process need to be in memory,

so we simply swap them out

  • swap processes temporarily out of memory to disk
  • bring back into memory for continue execution
  • requires swap space(which can be a file or partiiton on disk)
  • Transfer time is the major part of swap time

sometimes the computer is doing nothing because it is moving threads in and out instead of executing the threads

so by constantly moving the threads it provides the illusion of running all the threads at once

docs.title: Virtual memory
docs.text:
separation of user logical memory from physical memory

since logical address space can be much larger than physical address space

this can be done with paging or segmentation

docs.title: paging:
docs.text:
so the logical address space of process can be noncontiguous, the processes are allocated physical memoty when available

we have frames

  • fixed-size blocks of physical memory
  • keep track of all free frames

pages

  • block of sam e size logical memory

To run program of size n pages

  • find n free frames and load program
  • set up a page table

this is then pass to the MMU(hardware) for converting logical address to physical address

What is the advantage of a paged virtual memory system with a (a) small page size and (b) large page size

with a small page size, you can allocate more threads accurately(imply less internal fragmentation, even if you request 1 byte, the OS gives you a whole page), so more efficient memory use

with a large page size, you can write more code in the thread and less mapping to do so faster, less overhead for address translation

Describe how a context switch affects the virtual memory system

the context switch basically moves the thread not running to other place and the running thread to the main memory

(we dont always need all the process in the memory?)

we can have multiple page tables and switch them when we need to run another process

docs.title: Adrdress Translation:
docs.text:
the address generated by the CPU can be divided into

Page number (p)

  • Used as index into page table
  • Page table has base address of pages in physical memory

Page offset (d)

  • Defines physical memory address sent to MMU
  • combines with base address

so we have

this is what the MMU does, we keep the offset and translate the page number in the page table

by using paging, everything is the same size, so it reduces external memory fragementation

docs.title: memory protection:
docs.text:
this is implementaed by associating protection bits with pages

so there is a valid-invalid bit attached to each page table entry:

if valid: legel page

  • associated page in process; logical address space

if Invalid: page is missing

  • page not in process' logical address space(page fault)
  • need to load the page(demand paging)
  • Incorrect access(program error)

null is a address it always point to 0

docs.title: exam question:
docs.text:
An embedded system uses a 16-bit big-endian architecture. It supports virtual memory management with a one-level page table. It has a page size of 1 KByte. Each page table entry contains the frame's physical address; the least significant bit represents a valid bit; the second least significant bit is the modified (dirty) bit.

The following are the current entries in the page table (in hexadecimal notation):

  • 0x2C00 valid bit 0,
  • 0x0403
  • 0xCC01
  • 0x0000
  • 0x7C01

Translate the following virtual memory addresses to physical memory addresses using the page table given above (if possible):

  • (i) 0xB85
  • (ii) 0x1420 (page fault beyound end)
  • (iii) 0x1000
  • (iv) 0xC9A (page fault invalid)

1Kb = \(2^{10} b\) so 10 significant bits

we only use the least 10 bits

so \(0xB85 = 0p\underbrace_{p}{0000 10}|\underbrace_{d}{11 1000 0101}\)

so we should go to the second entry in the page table

which is 0xCC01, 1100 11|00 0000 0001

we check the valid bit, valid bit 1

then we map the page number p to the physical address

0000 10 -> 1100 11

so the final address

is 1100 1111 1000 0101

the dirty bit means nothing for now

docs.title: page table implementation
docs.text:
page table is kept in main memory

  • Page table base register(PTBR) points to page
  • Page table length register(RTLR) indicates size

the problem is inefficient - every data/instruction access requires two memory accesses: one for page table and one for data/instruction

the MMU in segmentation does arithmetical operations(base and limit registers),, but MMU in paging needs to look up stuff in the page table

so we cache

docs.title: associative memory:
docs.text:
Solution: use special fast-lookup hardware cache as associative memory

Associative memory: Supports parallel search

for translation(p,d)

  • if p in associative register, get the frame # out
  • otherwise get frame # from page table in the memory

docs.title: Translation Look-aside Buffers(TLBs)
docs.text:
SOme TLBs store address-space ids(ASIDs) in entries

  • this uniquely identifies each process to provide address-space protection for that process

TLBs usually needs to be flushed after context switch (each process has its own page table, so not flushing causes errors)

  • can lead to substantial overhead(every instruction would call the TLB)
  • for kernel pages for system calls, it is the same for every process or thread, so we dont need to flush the entire TLB, we only need to flush those related to the user pages

the page table should be somewhere that only the OS kernel can access, not the user

so this is the MMU that is implmented today

docs.title: Performance: Effective Access Time
docs.text:
Associative Lookup = \(\epsilon\)

Assume memory cycle time = 1 \(\mu\) sec

Hit ratio \(\alpha\)

  • the fraction of times that page found in associative refister
  • ratio related to number of associative registers

Effective Access Time(EAT) - \(EAT = (\epsilon + 1)\alpha + (\epsilon + 2)(1-\alpha) =2 + \epsilon - \alpha\)

when hit, we do \(\epsilon + 1\) (1 for the memory cycle time) and times the ratio

when miss we do two matches(1 in the associative and miss and another in the memory)

docs.title: Page table types
docs.text:
• Hierarchical page table
  • Hashed page table
  • Inverted page table

docs.title: Hierachical page table
docs.text:
this make use of two-level paging

this form a 3-level tree with the outer page table -> page table -> memory

Two level Paging:

THe logical address is divided(assuming 32bit machine with 1K 2^10b page size)

  • page number 22 bits
  • page offset 10 bits

the page table is paged so the page number

  • 12 bit page number
  • 10 bit offset

so you get something like

| p1 | p2 | d |

today's machine has 4 levels and moving to 5 (active field of research)

the EAT would then be \((\epsilon + 1)\alpha + (\epsilon + 3)(1 - \alpha) = 3 + \epsilon -\alpha\)

on 32-bit machine with 4kb pages - page table will be at leas 4MB (4B * 2^(32-12))

on 64-bit machine - page table needs 2^52 entries, if 8bytes, 30 million GB

so dont store entry per page but per frame

docs.title: hashed page table
docs.text:
Hash virtual page number into page table

  • page table contains chain of elements hashing to the same location
  • search for match virtual page number in chain
  • extract corresonding physical frame if match found

docs.title: inverted Page table
docs.text:
entry for each page frame of memory consisting of

  • virtual address of page stored in that memory location
  • information about process that owns the page

this decrease memory needed to store page table. but increases time to search table when page reference occurs

we use hash table to limit search to one or few entries

When two threads access shared data without mutual exclusion, a race condition is present - True \(\times\) - False \(\checked\)

access can be just reading, in this case there is no race-condition

In pintos a common synchronisation method is to simply disable interrupts to prevent preemption & thus ensure excusive access to shared data. Why may this strategy work for Pintos, but is less applicable and far more complex in modern operating systems running on modern CPUs. - Pintos runs on a single core processor (i386), so disabling interrupts stops any preemption and ensures exclusive access to everything. \(\checked\) - Modern CPUs cannot disable interrupts so cannot use this type of synchronisation

Which of the following advantages of Perterson's solution over Strict Alternation?

  • No threads outside the critical section can prevent another from entering the critical section \(\checked\)
  • Mutual exclusion is ensured \(\checked\)
  • A thread can exit and re-enter the critical region without the other having to enter the critical section between(No alternation) \(\checked\)

recall Peterson' Solution

C
// outside the threads
int turn = 0; 
int interested[2] = {0, 0};
// thread is 0 or 1
void enter_critical(int thread) 
{
  int other = 1 – thread;
  interested[thread] = 1;
  turn = other;
  while (turn == other && 
        interested[other])
    /* loop */ ;
}
void leave_critical(int thread) 
{ 
  interested[thread] = 0;
}

recall strict alternation

C
// TO
while (true) {
   while (turn != 0) 
     /* loop */ ;
   critical_section()
   turn = 1;

  noncritical_section0();
}

// T1
while (true) {
  while (turn != 1) 
    /* loop */ ;
  critical_section()
  turn = 0;

noncritical_section1();
}

the question asks the advantage of peterson's over strict alternation

both of them enres mutual exclusion, but in strict alternation, if one of the threads executes for a very long time and the turn is never altered, you could get the thread never executes

Also there is no alternation in Peterson's

The producer-consumer pattern is present in a previously visited UNIX concept. What UNIX feature/concept is this?

pipes

some race conditions I could think of is

\(\begin{array}{c|r} \text{lock(&my_lock)} & \text{thread 1}\\ \downarrow\\ \text{temp_b1 = b} & \text{thread 1}\\ \downarrow\\ \text{b = temp_b1 + 1} & \text{thread 1}\\ \downarrow\\ \text{unlock(&my_lock)} & \text{thread 1}\\ \downarrow\\ \hline \text{a mixure of the }\textbf{a}\text{ operations}\\ \text{since }\textbf{a}\text{ is not protected by locks} & \text{race coditions}\\ \text{there is a race condition}\\ \hline \downarrow\\ \text{lock(&my_lock)} & \text{thread 0}\\ \downarrow\\ \text{temp_b0 = b} & \text{thread 0}\\ \downarrow\\ \text{b = temp_b0 + 1} & \text{thread 0}\\ \downarrow\\ \text{unlock(&my_lock)} & \text{thread 0}\\ \end{array}\)
we have to follow the ordering

What technique feature will you implement in Pintos to help reduce priority inversion

  • Multilevel Feedback Queue
  • Priority Donation for Locks \(\checked\)
  • Reentrant Locks
  • Priority Donation for Semaphores

Is it possible to deadlock with only a single thread/process?

it is, deadlock can occur when a single thread waits for a signal forever(acquiring the lock twice without release)

What is the acronym for the common atomic operation of setting a boolean to true, and returning its old value

TSL(test and set lock)

A student is writing a basic program to test on their task 1 submission

They are given a basic multithreaded program making use of a type of lock implemented in the program itself.

With priority donation on (MLFQs off), the program's main thread (highest priority) remains scheduled and is not blocked, but does not progress (no print on standard output).

The student suspects the lock implementation used by the program to be at fault. What type of lock does the student suspect is being used.

docs.title: lecture5-Deque
docs.text:
amotised complexity

similar to the average

in practise, examples: (data structures have invariances)

so we have

\(\begin{array}{c|c} O(1) & O(n)\\ cons & snoc\\ head & last\\ tail & init \end{array}\)

we want all of those to be \(O(1)\)

docs.title: Deque
docs.text:
Haskell
data Deque a = Deque Int [a] [a] derving show

given x = [1,2,3]

we have the following Deque

Text Only
[
  Deque [1,2,3] [],
  Deque [1,2] [3],
  Deque [1] [3,2],
  Deque [] [3,2,1]
]

the invariance is xs = us ++ revers sv for Deque us sv (the toList function)

so we can give this instance of Deque

Haskell
instance Seq Deque where
  toList :: Deque -> [a]
  toList (Deque n us sv) = us ++ reverse sv

  nil :: Deque a
  nil = Deque 0 [] []
  -- (to be continued)

Currently we have one invariance, it is not enough

Haskell
  -- (continued)
  cons :: a -> Deque a -> Deque a -- O(1)
  cons i (Deque n us sv) = Deque (n+1) (u:us) sv

  snoc :: Deque a -> a -> Deque a
  snoc (Deque n us sv) i = Deque (n+1) us (v:sv)
  -- (to be continued)

symmetry is appealing

Haskell
  -- (continued)
  fromList :: [a] -> Deque a
  fromList a = Deque (Seq.length a) a []

this definition make last asymetric

Haskell
  -- (continued)
  fromList
Haskell
last (conds 1 (cons 2 (cons nil))) = last (Deque 3 [1,2,3] [])

head (nil `snoc` 1 `snoc` 2 `snoc` 3) = head (Deque 3 [] [3,2,1])

we want it to be some what balanced, we add a second invariance

Haskell
-- implications
(==>) :: Bool -> Bool -> Bool
False ==> _ = True
True ==> p = p

we will add an invariance for rebalancing

Haskell
(null sv ==> length us <= 1) && (null us ==> length sv <= 1)

-- or 

(n >= 2) ==> not (null us) && not (null vs)

this is enough to give us constant time head and last

Haskell
head :: Deque a -> a
head (Deque _ [] [v]) = v -- O(1)
head (Deque _ (u:us) _) = u -- O(1)

last :: Deque a -> a
last (Deque _ [v] []) = v -- O(1)
last (Deque _ _ (u:us)) = u -- O(1)

symmetrical

Haskell
cons :: a -> Deque a -> Deque a -- O(1)
cons u (Deque n sv []) = Deque (n+1) [u] sv
cons u (Deque n us sv) = Deque (n+1) (u:us) sv

snoc :: Deque a -> a -> Deque a -- O(1)
snoc (Deque n [] us) v = Deque (n+1) us [v]
snoc (Deque n us sv) v = Deque (n+1) us (v:sv)

now the head, last, cons, snoc are all O(1)

Haskell
tail :: Deque a -> Deque a -- O(n) in worst case, ~O(1)
tail (Deque 0 _ _) = undefined -- O(1)
tail (Deque 1 _ _) = nil -- O(1) -- we dont care what is inside, there is only one element in the Deque
-- tail (Deque n [u] sv) = Deque (n-1) [] sv -- this is illegal, possibly break the invariance
tail (Deque _ [_] sv) = fromList (reverse sv) -- O(n)
tail (Deque _ (_:us) sv) = Deque (n-1) us sv

init :: Deque a -> Deque a -- O(n) in worst case, ~O(1)
init (Deque 0 _ _) = undefined
init (Deque 1 _ _) = nil
init (Deque _ us [_] ) = fromList us
init (Deque n us (_:sv)) = Deque (n-1) us sv

analytically, the functions is O(n), but this is not the case

so the amortization illustates that we overpay and pay back we we have to do some extra operation(in this case, the rebalancing)

docs.title: amortizaed analysis
docs.text:
we need three things

  • A cost function \(C_{op_i}(xs_i)\), this is the true cost of the operation opi st the state xsi
  • An amortized cost function \(A_{op_i}(xs_i)\) this is the amortised cost of opi when applied to xsi
  • A "potential" function (assume we are scientists), \(\Phi (xs)\) a measure of how expensive the next operation will be, >= 0

Basically, these three functions will form a relationship

\(C_{opi}(xs_i) \le A_{op_i}(xs) - (\Phi(xs') - Phi(xs))\)

if this relationship is true, then the operation wil have complexity \(A_{op}\)

summing up the both sides gives

\(\sum_{i=0}^n C_{op_i}(xs_i) \le \sum_{i=0} A_{op_i}(xs_i) (\text{here, all the }\Phi\text{cancelles out})\)

so

\(\sum_{i=0}^n C_{op_i}(xs_i) + \Phi(xs) \le \sum_{i=0} A_{op_i}(xs_i) (\text{here, all the }\Phi\text{cancelles out})\)

since

\(\Phi(xs) \ge 0\) as we define it

docs.title: Re: analysis
docs.text:
Haskell
tail :: Deque a -> Deque a -- ~O(1)
tail (Deque 0 _ _) = undefined -- O(1)
tail (Deque 1 _ _) = nil -- O(1)
tail (Deque _ [_] sv) = fromList (reverse sv) -- O(n)
tail (Deque _ (_:us) sv) = Deque (n-1) us sv -- O(1)

\(\begin{aligned} C_{tail}(\text{Deque 1 _ _}) &= 1\\ C_{tail}(\text{Deque _ [_] _}) &= n\\ C_{tail}(\text{Deque _ (_:_) _}) &= 1 \end{aligned}\)

and

\(\begin{aligned} A_{tail}(xs) = k &\text{we assume this is } O(1)\\ \end{aligned}\)

\(\Phi(\text{Deque _ us sv}) = \max((\text{length sv} - \text{length us}), 0)\)

so

\(C_{op_i} \le A_{op_i} - (\Phi(xs') - \Phi(xs_i))\)

so

\(\begin{aligned} C_{tail}(\text{Deque 1 _ _})&\le A_{tail}(\text{Deque 1 _ _}) - (\Phi(nil) - \Phi(Deque 1 _ _))\\ 1 \end{aligned}\)

$$

docs.title: Knapsack
docs.text:
(带价值的背包)

quick reference (CHN): https://oi.wiki/dp/knapsack/

sample solution (to be altered in the problems)

Haskell
knapsack :: forall name weight value . (Ord weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)]-> weight-> value
knapsack wvs c = maximumElse 0 [ v + knapsack wvs (c- w) | (_,w,v) <- wvs , w <= c ]

wvs is the set of objects, c is the max capacity of the knapsack

so basically, it is just maximizing value + knapsack wvs (c-w)

a classic problem of backpack DP, with infinite items

where

Haskell
maximumElse :: Ord a => a-> [a]-> a
maximumElse x xs = foldr max x xs

docs.title: problem 1 knapsack with DP
docs.text:
Use dynamic programmingto improve the running time of knapsack, by giving a definition of mknapsack in Optimise.hs.

Haskell

knapsack' :: forall name weight value . (Ix weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)]-> weight-> value
knapsack' wvs c = table ! c
  where
    table :: Array weight value
    table = tabulate (0,c) mknapsack
    mknapsack :: weight-> value
    mknapsack c = undefined
Hint: compare the recursive version of fib with the dynamic programming version to see how to translate one to the other

the basic idea is we have the following formula, since wvs is always the same, we only tabulate upon c

\(f(c) = \max (f(c - obj_w) + obj_v), \forall obj\in wvs\)

the table is just a array of possible all possible f

Haskell
knapsack' :: forall name weight value. (Ix weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)] -> weight -> value
knapsack' wvs c = table ! c
  where table :: Array weight value
        table = tabulate (0, c) mknapsack

        mknapsack :: weight -> value
        mknapsack c = maximum (0:[v + table ! (c-w) | (_, w, v) <- wvs, w <= c]) -- this zero here is to prevent mknapsack runs into maximum []

docs.title: time strict:
docs.text: each time we iterate through the list of items we can pick \(O(n)\), retrieving takes \(O(1)\), cons with the Prelude List take \(O(1)\), maximum needs \(O(n)\) (we have to iterate through the list to find the max), so thats \(O(c(n+n)) = O(2cn) = O(cn)\) if the number of objects is n, in this case we assum haskell is strict and all the items in the table needs to be evaluated

docs.title: time lazy:
docs.text:
In this implementation, I dont think there is any difference, maximum requires all the element in the list to be known, which is the same as strict

for the coin changing example in lectures, extreme cases may happen, leading to variances in complexity??

since the coins only care about the last while we care about all or max in knapsack

docs.title: problem 2 knapsack with DP with list of names
docs.text:
Implement knapsack'' as a modified version of knapsack' so that it outputs the maximum value of the knapsack, as well as a list of the element indices that are chosen to obtain that value.

Hint: You may need to make use of maximumBy to be able to ignore the indices that are being used. A fantastic site for finding useful functions is https://hoogle.haskell.org/, where even type signatures can be typed in.

the same, just add the list of name as an additional output

Haskell
knapsack'' :: forall name weight value. (Ix weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)] -> weight -> (value, [name])
knapsack'' wvs c = table ! c
  where table :: Array weight (value, [name])
        table = tabulate (0,c) mknapsack

        mknapsack :: weight -> (value, [name])
        mknapsack c = (foldr (maxBy valueCmp)) (0,[]) ([let (v', ns) = table ! (c - w) in (v + v', n:ns) | (n, w, v) <- wvs, w <= c])
        -- I dont really want to use maximumBy, since it can be done without importing
          where valueCmp :: (value, [name]) -> value
                valueCmp (somev, _) = somev

time complexity does not change \(O(cn)\) for strict and lazy

docs.title: problem3 knapsack with non replacable items(bknapsack)
docs.text:
This is the type of bknapsack, which is similar to knapsack except that the elements are not replaced when picked. Haskell

bknapsack :: forall name weight value . (Ord weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)]-> weight-> (value, [name])
remove it from the recursive call.

Hint: Perform case analysis on the list of items. After using an item, To implement this function, first write a recursive definition, where the result of bknapsack wvs c is the maximum value that can be packed into a capacity of c from the elements of wvs by only using each element at most once

01-backpacks

just use the same as knapsack, need to subtract the selected item from the list

Haskell
-- knapsack with non-replaced finite items
-- turns to 01 backpack, for each item, we can only pick or not pick
-- this is still using the knapsack idea, but we alter the list
bknapsack :: forall name weight value. (Ord weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value, Eq name) => [(name, weight, value)] -> weight -> (value, [name])
bknapsack wvs c = (foldr (maxBy valueCmp)) (0,[]) [ let (v', ns) = bknapsack (filter (checkName n) wvs) (c - w) in (v + v', ns ++ [n]) | (n,w,v) <- wvs , w <= c ]
  -- so we inspect the rest elements, and pick the max possible outcome
  where checkName :: name -> (name, weight, value) -> Bool
        checkName n' (n, _, _) = n /= n'
        valueCmp :: (value, [name]) -> value
        valueCmp (somev, _) = somev

docs.title: complexity
docs.text: filter is \(O(n)\), so still \(O(cn)\)

docs.title: problem4 bknapsack with non altering
docs.text:
Write another recursive solution, bknapsack', to the bounded knap sack problem. This time, do not change the list in the recursion, but instead introduce another parameter that keeps track of progress. That is, bknapsack' wvs i will use only the first i (counting from 1) items in the list wvs.

Haskell
bknapsack' :: forall name weight value . (Ord weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)]-> Int-> weight-> (value, [name])

Hint: Take a careful look at the type signature, and notice the extra Int parameter. Use this to keep track of which part of the list has been processed.

for each element, we could only pick or not pick

i represent the first i elements we are allowed to pick

so \(f(i,c) = \max (f(i-1, c-w), f(i-1, c))\)

the rest are the same with knapsack'

Haskell
-- from the first i element to do the DP
bknapsack' :: forall name weight value. (Ord weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)] -> Int -> weight -> (value, [name])
bknapsack' [] _ _ = (0, [])        -- when it is an empty list, no items can be fetched
bknapsack' _ 0 c = (0, [])         -- when we are required to pick from the first 0 items, nothing can be fetched
                                   -- here, we should get a negative case, but I 'll assume the input is valid
bknapsack' ((n,w,v):wvs) 1 c       -- when we can only pick 1 item
  | w > c = (0, [])                -- does not meet requirement, nothing can be picked
  | otherwise = (v, [n])           -- meet requirement, the only pickable item
bknapsack' wvs i c                 -- general case
  | w > c = bknapsack' wvs (i-1) c -- if the current item is heavier than capacity, we could only discard it
  | otherwise = let (optv', ns) = bknapsack' wvs (i-1) (c - w) in maxBy valueCmp (bknapsack' wvs (i-1) c) (optv' + v, n: ns)
  -- other wise we pick it
-- we can either not pick this element so that the max is the last max
-- or pick, then recalculate a max based on previous results
  where (n, w, v) = wvs !! (i-1) -- we can only use the first i elements

        valueCmp :: (value, [name]) -> value
        valueCmp (somev, _) = somev

docs.title: complexity
docs.text:
still \(O(cn)\) for strict, we have to do \(O(cn)\) for lazy in the worst case

also, for all those problems, we have to calculate cn states, so at least \(O(cn)\), optimal?

docs.title: problem 5 bknapsack with DP
docs.text:
Using dynamic programming implement bknapsack'', which is the efficient version of bknapsack' that makes use of tables rather than repeated recursion.

Haskell
bknapsack'' :: forall name weight value . (Ord name, Ix weight, Ord weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)]-> weight-> (value, [name])

Hint: whenpopulating the table, use the new Int parameter instead of the input list as part of the index.

Hint: The Array type can be indexed by any type that has an Ix instance. Notably, tuples of indexable types are also indexable, which means for example it is possible to have an array of type Array (Int, Int) Bool, which can be thought of as a two dimensional array

same as 4, but contruct a two dimensional table, one dimension for i, another for c

Haskell
bknapsack'' :: forall name weight value. (Ord name, Ix weight, Ord weight, Num weight, Ord value, Num value) => [(name, weight, value)] -> weight -> (value, [name])
bknapsack'' wvs c = table ! (l, c)
  where l = length wvs
        table = tabulate ((0,0),(l,c)) (uncurry bkhelper) -- DP array
        bkhelper :: Int -> weight -> (value, [name])
        bkhelper 0 _ = (0, [])        -- we are required to pick 0 elements
        bkhelper _ x                  -- inspect the input
          | x <= 0 = (0,[])           -- negative invalid input
        bkhelper 1 c                  -- we are required to pick only 1 element
          | w > c = (0, [])           -- does not meet requirement
          | otherwise = (v, [n])      -- meets requirement
          where (n,w,v) = wvs !! 0    -- the first and only element we are allowed to pick
        bkhelper i j
          | j < w = table ! (i-1, j) -- we cannot pick the current element due to capacity
          | otherwise = let (optv, ns) = table ! (i-1, j-w) in maxBy valueCmp (table ! (i-1, j)) (optv + v, n:ns)
                                      -- we can pick, so we choose the max between pick and not pick
          where (n, w, v) = wvs !! (i-1)
                valueCmp :: (value, [name]) -> value
                valueCmp (somev, _) = somev

also, for all those problems, we have to calculate cn states, so at least \(O(cn)\), optimal?

docs.title: problem 6: dijkstra
docs.text:
Finish the implementation of dijkstra in ShortestPaths.hs by completing the definitions for us' and ps''. us' is the new list of unvisited nodes to consider in the recursive call, and ps'' is the updated priority queue ps' with the new candidates inserted into it. This case corresponds to step 3 from the above description.

Hint: You might find foldr useful for updating the shortest path candidates.

quick reference (CHN): https://oi.wiki/graph/shortest-path/

first inspect the sample code

Haskell
dijkstra :: forall g e v pqueue. (Graph g e v, PQueue pqueue) => g -> [v] -> pqueue (Path e) -> [Path e]
dijkstra g [] ps = []
dijkstra g us ps
  | isEmpty ps  = []
  | t `elem` us =
      let us' :: [v]
          us' = undefined -- TODO: Problem 6
          ps'' :: pqueue (Path e)
          ps'' = undefined -- TODO: Problem 6
      in p : dijkstra g us' ps''
  | otherwise  = dijkstra g us ps'
  where
    (p, ps') = detach ps
    t = target p

the parameters are clear in the case, g -> the graph, us -> fringe, ps -> candidate segments

when we process a segment that have target point outside the fringe list, it means we have already met the point before and should not add this segment again

otherwise, the point is being visited, remove it out of the fringe, detch removes p out of ps, merge the current segment with the later paths with expand, job done

Haskell
dijkstra :: forall g e v pqueue. (Graph g e v, PQueue pqueue) => g -> [v] -> pqueue (Path e) -> [Path e]
dijkstra g [] ps = []
dijkstra g us ps
  | isEmpty ps  = []
  | t `elem` us =
      let us' :: [v]
          us' = filter (\x -> x /= t) us
          ps'' :: pqueue (Path e)
          ps'' =  toPQueue cmpPath (psList' ++ (map (extend p) (edgesFrom g t)))
          -- pqueue is not foldable
          -- this should be, ps' (or ps without p) + all the edges that start from t
          -- also, we need to combine the paths
      in p : dijkstra g us' ps''
  | otherwise  = dijkstra g us ps'
  where
    (p, ps') = detach ps
    t = target p
    psList' = fromPQueue ps'

but note this is not the dijsktra as we learned, it calculate the shortest path from the point to every other point as a by-product, more like MST

docs.title: complexity:
docs.text:
if a graph has n nodes an m edges

then we need to find the min edge \(O(m)\), then we need to do this for each node in the iteration

fromPQueue is \(O(1)\), toPQueue is \(O(m\log m)\) (it sorts) so we can do better than this if we can discard toPQueue

however this would be impossible in the PQueue implementation, we can only get the edges to be extended by getting a List and then sort it, or do the one stated above, which cannot discard the toPQueue

this is definitely not the optimal solution, the PQueue PList we implemented in the coursework is not the binary heap we are familiar with, binary heap take \(O(\log m)\) to update the priorities, swapping if necessary, but sorting takes \(O(m\log m)\)

so this current take \(O(mn\log m)\), but using heap would make it \(O((m+n)\log n)\) since detach would need to reheapify the heap, taking more complexity

docs.title: problem 7 merging trees
docs.text:
Implement the mergeTree operation which merges two leftist trees. Haskell

mergeTree :: (a-> a-> Ordering)-> Tree a-> Tree a-> Tree a
mergeTree cmp l r = undefined

If either tree is empty, the result should be the other tree. When merging two nodes, first find out which tree should be merged into which (such that the root is always the smallest element in the tree), then recursively merge one tree into the right subtree of the other, potentially swapping at the end if the resulting right tree is taller than the left. Merging into the right (shorter) subtree ensures that the tree never gets too unbalanced. This in turn means that we will always have a logarithmic upper bound on the depth at each merge.

Hint: use the node smart constructor to maintain the rank invariant

nothing to say, pretty simple

Haskell
mergeTree :: (a -> a -> Ordering) -> Tree a -> Tree a -> Tree a
mergeTree _ Nil a = a
mergeTree _ a Nil = a
mergeTree cmp l@(Node rankl ll la lr) r@(Node rankr rl ra rr)
  | (lte cmp) la ra = node ll la (mergeTree cmp lr r) -- la is less or equal to ra, l should be the root
  | otherwise = node rl ra (mergeTree cmp rr l)

docs.title: complexity:
docs.text:
we first take a look at node

Haskell
node :: Tree a -> a -> Tree a -> Tree a
node l x r
  | hl < hr   = Node (hl + 1) r x l
  | otherwise = Node (hr + 1) l x r
 where
  hl = rankTree l
  hr = rankTree r

rankTree takes \(O(1)\) obviously, so the entire node takes \(O(1)\)

then we have (maybe not precise, I will skip most part and omit some obviously O(1))

\(\text{T_mergeTree}(\text{cmp l r}) = \text{T_lte} + \text{T_cmp} + \text{node} + \text{T_mergeTree}(cmp rr l) = O(1) + \text{T_mergeTree}\)

so if the num of nodes in the left tree is n and the right tree is m, then here is the interesting point

node may not always preserve a balanced tree on some extreme inputs, consider the arguments involve a singleton and a huge tree where all the right nodes are empty, all the child node are on the left, forming a line to make it extremely unbalanced

if it is balanced perfectly, optimal complexity \(O(\log(n+m))\) base on logarithms in the height

if not, worst case can be \(O(n+m)\), so it depends

docs.title: problem 8
docs.text:
Provide the instance of PQueue that shows how a heap can be used as a priority queue, by filling out the following definitions:

Hint: insertion can be thought of as a special case of merging.

just follow PQueue PList, they are similar, insert is just merging with a singleton Tree

Haskell
instance PQueue Heap where
  priority :: Heap a -> (a -> a -> Ordering)
  priority (Heap cmp _) = cmp

  empty :: (a -> a -> Ordering) -> Heap a
  empty p = Heap p Nil

  isEmpty :: Heap a -> Bool
  isEmpty (Heap _ Nil) = True
  isEmpty _ = False

  insert :: a -> Heap a -> Heap a
  insert x h = mergeHeap (Heap (priority h) (Node 1 Nil x Nil)) h

  extract :: Heap a -> a
  extract (Heap cmp (Node r _ a _)) = a
  extract _ = error "extract from empty heap"

  discard :: Heap a -> Heap a
  discard (Heap cmp (Node _ l _ r)) = Heap cmp (mergeTree cmp l r)

so node makes is always balanced(optimal)

  • priority, empty, isEmpty are obviouly \(O(1)\)
  • insert is \(O(\log n)\)
  • extract is \(O(1)\)
  • discard is \(O(\log n)\)

worst case

  • priority, empty, isEmpty are obviouly \(O(1)\)
  • insert is \(O(n)\)
  • extract is \(O(1)\)
  • discard is \(O(n)\)

docs.title: problem 9
docs.text:
Implement an adjacency list representation that supports efficient lookup of the edges from a planet by filling in the following interface.

Haskell

instance (Eq e, Edge e v) => Graph (AdjList e v) e v where
  vertices (AdjList ves) = undefined
  edges (AdjList ves) = undefined
  edgesFrom (AdjList ves) s = undefined
  edgesTo (AdjList ves) t = undefined
  velem v (AdjList ves) = undefined
  eelem e (AdjList ves) = undefined
Hint: You may use the standard list operations given in Data.List. You may also find list comprehensions useful.

Haskell
instance (Eq e, Edge e v) => Graph (AdjList e v) e v where
  vertices  (AdjList ves)   = concatMap (\(v, _) -> [v]) ves -- O(n) concatMap
  edges     (AdjList ves)   = concatMap (\(_, e) -> e) ves -- O(n) concatMap
  edgesFrom aves@(AdjList ves) s = filter (\e -> source e == s) (edges aves) -- O(n + n) = O(n)
  edgesTo   aves@(AdjList ves) t = filter (\e -> target e== t) (edges aves) -- O(n + n) = O(n)
  velem v   aves@(AdjList ves)   = v `elem` (vertices aves) -- O(n + 1) = O(n)
  eelem e   aves@(AdjList ves)   = e `elem` (edges aves) -- O(n + 1) = O(n)

docs.title: problem 10
docs.text:
In ShortestPaths.hs, define conflictZones, where conflictZones st p qtakes in the game state st, and two planet IDs p and q, and returns a triple (ps, pqs, qs) where ps are the identities of planets that can be reached by p first, qs are the identities of planets that can be reached by q first, and pqs are the identities of planets that can be reached by both at the same time.

Haskell
conflictZones :: GameState-> PlanetId-> PlanetId-> ([PlanetId], [PlanetId], [PlanetId])

Note that this should only be a function of the topology of the game: it does not need to take into account the number of ships garrisoned on planets, whether conquering is needed, the positions of fleets that are in flight or any other details

we check through all the nodes, and compare the distance of the paths

Haskell
conflictZones :: GameState -> PlanetId -> PlanetId -> ([PlanetId], [PlanetId], [PlanetId])
conflictZones st p q = foldr (\x (ps, pqs, qs) -> if whoFirst x == 1 
                                                    then (x:ps, pqs, qs) 
                                                  else if whoFirst x == 0 
                                                    then (ps, x:pqs, qs) 
                                                  else if whoFirst x == -1 
                                                    then (ps, pqs, x:qs) 
                                                  else (ps, pqs, qs)) ([],[],[]) alltargets
  where alltargets = vertices st

        whoFirst :: PlanetId -> Int
        whoFirst t
          | shortestp == Nothing && shortestq == Nothing = -2-- no one can reach, just give some random ints
          | shortestp == Nothing = -1                        -- q wins directly
          | shortestq == Nothing =  1                        -- p wins directly
          | otherwise = let Just (Path wp _) = shortestp     -- we are certain that this is not nothing
                            Just (Path wq _) = shortestq     -- we are certain that this is not nothing
                            in if wp > wq then -1 else if wp == wq then 0 else 1         
          where shortestp = shortestPath p t st
                shortestq = shortestPath q t st

docs.title: complexity
docs.text:
we first assume shortestPath is \(O((m+n)\log n)\) using Heap

then whoFirst would take \(O((m+n)\log n)\)

it repeats for all vertices \(O(n(m+n)\log n)\)

as shortesPath is proven optimal in dijsktra, we at least have to do dijstra n times

this is optimal

qsort uses ++ on lists to build up the output list; reimplement it to use the DLists, Compare the running time(both asymptotic and absolute) of the new qsort to the old

Haskell
qsort :: [Int] -> [Int]
qsort [] = []
qsort [x] = [x]
qsort (x:xs) = qsort us ++ [x] ++ qsort vs
  -- ++ takes constant time
  -- but partition is still O(n), (in the lecture)
  -- so still linear complexity
  where
    (us,vs) = partition (<= x) xs

the time complexity of this qsort asymptotically \(O(n\log n)\)

recall

Haskell
data DList a = DList ([a] -> [a])

instance Seq DList where
  toList (DList dxs) = dxs [] -- O(n)
  fromList xs        = DList (xs ++) -- O(1)

  nil               = DList id

so we have

Haskell
qsort :: [Int] -> [Int]
qsort = toList . go
  where 
    go :: [Int] -> DList Int
    go [] = nil
    go (x:xs) = (go vs) `append` (single x) `append` (go us)
    -- recall the single in the last tutorial
      where
        us,vs = partition (<= x) xs

and we have the tangent, using function composition

Haskell
qsort' xs = go xs []
  where
    go [] ks = id ks -- can use eta reduce
    go (x:xs) ks = (go vs) . (x :) . (go us)
      where 
        (us, vs) = partition (<= x) xs

Identify and prove that one of the base cases in the given definition of qsort is uncessary

the qsort [x] = [x]

Haskell
qsort [x] = qsort' us ++ [x] ++ qsort vs
  where
    (us,vs) = partition (<= x) []
= qsort us ++ [x] ++ qsort vs
  where
    (us,vs) = [], []
= qsort [] ++ [x] ++ qsort []
= [] ++ [x] ++ []
= [x]

Recall that quick sort is O(n^2) on sorted lists. With this in mind, often we employ more sophisticated methods of choosing a pivot: the median-of-three approach, for instance, picks the first, middle, and last elements in the input list and chooses the median of those three as the pivot. Calculate the time complexity of quick sort on sorted lists when median-of-three is used. Describe a pathological case, if one exists, where quick sort is O(n^2) even when median-of three is used.

on sorted lists,

consider 1,2,3,4,5

pick 3 as pivot qsort [1,2] ++ [3] ++ qsort [4,5]

(qsort [1] ++ [2] ++ [3] ++ qsort [4] ++ [5])

if we use median on a sorted lists, it is the ideal pivot, complexity \(O(n\log n)\)

the bas case is when you always pick the second largest or second smallest number

Consider the following implementation of merge sort on nonempty lists(equivalent to the implementation give in lectures)

rewrite foldt to be bottom-up(rather than top-down): it should merge adjacent elements in the input list repeatedly until only one is left, and then return it.

Haskell
merge :: [Int] -> [Int]
merge [] ys = ys
merge xs [] = xs
merge xxs@(x:xs) yys@(y:ys)
  | x <= y    = x:merge xs yys
  | otherwise = y:merge xxs ys
Haskell
msort :: [Int] -> [Int]
msort = foldt merge . map single

foldt :: (a -> a -> a) -> [a] -> a
foldt _ [x] = x
foldt f xs = f (foldt f ys) (foldt y zs)
  where 
    (ys,zs) = splitAt (length xs `div` 2) xs

so bottom up means to do from leaves too root

docs.title: Exercise 1
docs.text:
Sepecify a Turning Machine (TM) \(M = (Q, \sum, s, \delta)\) which starts a tape with the representation of a list \(L = [x_1, x_2,\dots, x_n]\)(as in lectures) and terminates with a tape representing the (singleton) list [s] where

\(s = n + \sum_{i=1}^n x_i\)

Describe the computational steps (configuration) of M when the initial tape represents the list [1,2,3]

the tape starts with [1,2,3]

should end with [9]

let B represent the blank symbol

\([1,2,3] = BBB01B11B1110BBB\)

\([9] = BBB01111111110BBB\)

so we could do this

we first define the states set \(Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3, q_4, q_5\}\) with

  • \(q_0\): just entered the program, currently point at 0
  • \(q_1\): current pointing 1, still not reach the right end
  • \(q_2\): current pointing B still not reach the right end
  • \(q_3\): current pointing 0, reached the right end
  • \(q_4\): current pointing B, should be the new right end
  • \(q_5\): finished changing, return to start

we have the Turning Machine

\(Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3, q_4, q_5\}, \sum = \{B,0,1\}, s = q_0, \delta\) would be demostrated below with a graph

then we have the computing process, we assume the starting position is the leftmost 0. When the initial tape is [1,2,3], the computation will be as follows, (I assume the current tape head is at the leftmost symbol of the third term in configuration, (a, 0,B1) would mean tape head is point at B)

\(\begin{aligned} (q_0,B,01_11_1110BB) &\to _M(q_1,B0,1B11B1110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_2, 01,B11B1110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_1, 011, 11B1110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_1, 0111, 1B1110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_2, 01111, B1110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_1, 011111, 1110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_1, 0111111, 110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_1, 01111111, 10BB)\\ &\to _M(q_3, 011111111, 0BB)\\ &\to _M(q_4, 0111111111, BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 011111111, 10BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 01111111, 110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 0111111, 1110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 011111, 11110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 01111, 111110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 0111, 1111110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 011, 11111110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 01, 111111110BB)\\ &\to _M(q_5, 0, 1111111110BB)\\ \end{aligned}\)

docs.title: Exercise 2
docs.text: When would you say that two RMs are computing the same?How would you define formally that two RMs compute in the same way? Is it decidable if two RMs are computing the same or computing in the same way, respectively? Argue why or why not?

docs.title: I would say that two RM is computing the same:
docs.text:
(since is say, I dont think I need to formally define this)

they act the same, they both halts, and given any valid input, the output is always the same

I would consider that as long as they produce the same output on the same question, no matter what algorithms they use, no matter how twisted their program may be, they are computing the same

docs.title: I would define formally that two RM is computing the same:
docs.text:
I would define it as follows:

for any two RM: \(RM_1\) and \(RM_2\), they are considered computing the same if

first, they both halt

second, they use the same number of registers

third, given any configuration \(c\), let the next configuration of \(RM_1\) be \(fc_1\) and that of \(RM_2\) be \(fc_2\), then \(fc_1 = fc_2\).

docs.title: decidability
docs.text:
both no, because to decide whether they compute the same or in the same way, we have to decide whether they halt or not.

we do not know whether they halt or not because the halting question is known to be undecidable, thus we cannot satisfy the requirements for both definitions

therefore, for both definitions, it is not decidable

docs.title: Exercise 3
docs.text:
Describe graphically a Registe Machine (RM) M which sums up all the odd numbers up to a certain limit. More precisely, let

\[f(n) = \sum_{i=0}^n 2i + 1\]

then M should start with \(R_0 = n\) and \(R_1 = 0\) and terminate with \(R_0 = 0\) and \(R_1 = f(n)\)

Write down the program code or list of instructions for this machine M using only a single HALT instruction (at the end of the code)

Describe the executions fo M with initially \(R_0 = 0,1,2,3\)

Do all executions of M halt? Explain why or why not

docs.title: describe graphically:
docs.text:
the Register machine should form a loop, if we are using curved lines, then the execution graph should be like a big main circle and some small circles just on the edge of the big circle and a main line tagent to the main circle pointing directly at the HALT

it should look like this

(forgive me for using straight lines on the computer, I usually mess the lines up when I am drawing on the paper, lines and symbols would just intersect to form chaos)

docs.title: Describe the executions
docs.text:
if \(R_0 = 0\) then the loop would just add 1 to \(R_1\) and HALT

if \(R_0 = 1,2,3\), then the programs forms loop, each time we add 1 to another two registers \(R_2, R_3\), pass through a triangle shape doubler to double \(R_3\) and add the doubled \(R_3\) to \(R_1\), we then use the \(R_3\) to restore the value of \(R_2\) back, we also add 1 to \(R_1\) everytime in the loop for the +1 term. In addition, because \(2\times 0+1 = 1\) was not added in the loop, rather, when \(R_0\) is zero, we exit the loop directly, so we add this back at the end of the program

docs.title: whether M Halts
docs.text:
it HALTS regardless of \(R_0\)

if \(R_0 = 0\), the program would halt obviously, all it does is adding 1 to \(R_1\)

otherwise it also HALTS, no matter what value \(R_0\) is, assume it to be n, the real variable \(R_0\) in execution to be m, then the loop will executes for n times, \(R_2, R_3\) in the begining of the loop would be n-m, the doubler would execute \(3\times(n-m)\) times, copying \(R_2\) to \(R_3, R_4\) take another \(3\times(n-m)\) times, copying \(R_4\) back to \(R_2\) take \(2\times(n-m)\) times,

in each loop, there is an additional 6 executions beside the above, and 2 executions outside the loop

so the total executions would be, as m can be \(1\text{to}\infty\), \(2+\sum_{m=0}^{n-1}8\times(n-m)+6 = 4n(n+1) + 6n + 2\) which is finite

so the program always HALTS

docs.title: Part 4: In PintOS, a thread is characterized by a struct and an execution stack.
docs.text:
( the thread struct looks like this:

C

struct thread
  {
    /* Owned by thread.c. */
    tid_t tid;                          /* Thread identifier. */
    enum thread_status status;          /* Thread state. */
    char name[16];                      /* Name (for debugging purposes). */
    uint8_t *stack;                     /* Saved stack pointer. */
    int priority;                       /* Priority. */
    struct list_elem allelem;           /* List element for all threads list. */

    /* Shared between thread.c and synch.c. */
    struct list_elem elem;              /* List element. */

#ifdef USERPROG
    /* Owned by userprog/process.c. */
    uint32_t *pagedir;                  /* Page directory. */
#endif

    /* Owned by thread.c. */
    unsigned magic;                     /* Detects stack overflow. */
  };
)

docs.title: (a) What are the limitations on the size of these data structures?
docs.text: so we have the struct as shown above and a execution stack, there are some potential problems related to it 1. the stack it self consists of pointers, as a result, we have no information about what is inside the stack, for example, whether it is a char or a long 2. the thread dont not prevent other thread from altering what should be private, but I am currently not so sure how to fix this 3. if memory size is a concern, we may cut the name field as tid should be sufficient to identify the threads

docs.title: (b) Explain how this relates to stack overflow and how PintOS identifies if a stack overflow has occurred.
docs.text: pintos create a magic component in the thread to detect overflow. Normally the magic number is set to a random value and if something overflows. It exceeds it original size and start affecting the magic value. So to check overflow, we simply assert if the magic value remains the same. If not, overflow, otherwise maybe yes or does not matter.

docs.title: Part 5: Explain how thread scheduling in PintOS currently works in roughly 300 words. Include the chain of execution of function calls.(Hint: we expect you to at least mention which functions participate in a context switch, how they interact, how and when the thread state is modified and the role of interrupts.)
docs.text:
(This need fix) The scheduler it self first get the current thread and the next thread from the ready_list using running_thread() and next_thread_to_run(), if we need a switch or the next thread to run is different, we call switch_threads() to switch the thread.

The switch_threads() function would first store the state of the caller to %ebx, %ebp, %esi, %edi with pushl. Then we move the current stack pointer to the old thread's stack. This is the moment where the state of the old thread is modified. After this, we do a similar operation to the current state to restore the stack pointer. The final returned value is the caller's state in the altered context.

After this, we set the current thread runningm and if the previous thread is dying, null or is the initial thread, we destroy the previous thread.

These functions should execution is interruption is not enabled. As if we are interrupting, we set the inte_level, block the whatever is running in the CPU until the interruption flag sti is set again in intr_enable. Interruption makes sure that if something went wrong, we would not continue executing running threads in a wrong context.

the property of reproducibility illustrate that no matter what time you execute the program, if the parameter are the same, the output should be correspondingly consistent

If the program lacks reproducibility, you might find trouble determining what value it should be in the process and thus unable to identify potential errors

docs.title: Part 10: Define what is meant by a race-condition. Why is the test if(x != null) insufficient to prevent a segmentation fault from occurring on an attempted access to a structure through pointer x? (Hint: you should assume that the pointer variable is correctly typed, that the structure was successfully initialised earlier in the program and that there are other threads running in parallel.)
docs.text:
The race-condition is when two threads in parallel tries to alter the same resource at the same time. The uncertainty in the order the thread access the resource may cause chaos

Therefore, even if x != null, there is a possibility that everything is initialized properly, but say x is 1 at first, and should be x = 1 when thread A executes, but then a fast thread B alters x to 2 before A could even react.

/* Sleeps for approximately TICKS timer ticks.  Interrupts must
   be turned on. */
void
timer_sleep (int64_t ticks) 
{
  int64_t start = timer_ticks (); // to get the time tick at the start
  printf(">>>> Now sleping thread %s for %"PRIu64" ticks value", thread_current()->name, ticks);
  ASSERT (intr_get_level () == INTR_ON);
  // make sure the thread is not blocked, INTR_ON is one of the enum
  while (timer_elapsed (start) < ticks) 
  // while threads should sleep, yield
    thread_yield ();
}

void
thread_yield (void) 
{
  struct thread *cur = thread_current ();
  // get current thread
  enum intr_level old_level;
  // define the level
  ASSERT (!intr_context ());
  // make sure we are interrupting

  old_level = intr_disable ();
  // get the interruption disabled flag and stop the cpu thread
  if (cur != idle_thread) 
  // the idle_thread is a static struct thread
    list_push_back (&ready_list, &cur->elem);
    // if not idle then it should be in the ready list
  cur->status = THREAD_READY;
  // change the status back to ready
  schedule ();
  // schedule the thread
  intr_set_level (old_level);
  // interrupt with level
}

enum intr_level
intr_get_level (void) 
{
  uint32_t flags;

  asm volatile ("pushfl; popl %0" : "=g" (flags));

docs.title: code analysis
docs.text:
After the completion, let's looking into the code for a detailed analysis

basically it executes the init.c in the threads folder

it does a whole bunch of init

first, bss, read the cmd args, init the whole program as a thread,

init the memory etc.

so basically the program is a idle thread?

the idle thread is put on the ready list by thread_start() and it will be scheduled initially then never appears in the ready list

if the ready_list is empty, then next_thread_to_run() returnts the idle thread

the main stuff happens when the run_actions is called, the main function process the cli args

if run keyword is detected in run_actions() in init.c, then run_task function is called

if the user program is defined, then we do the normal setup, else we run the tests

the run_test function is in src/tests/threads/tests.h but since it is extern, it is actually in src/tests/devices/tests.h for pintos_task0_hg1523

then it assigns which task to run in the folder and executes the task

docs.title: pintos init:
docs.text:
Initial thread: - Initial thread is in src/threads/inti.c is started by the pintos boot (line 93 thread_init) - Initial thread starts the threading sub-system and “promotes” itself to a standard Pintos thread in thread_init() - Initial thread then initialises other subsystems (e.g. malloc, timer) - Initial thread then parses Pintos command-line arguments - Initial thread then starts other threads, via thread_create()

test are running by in the init.c

C
/* Runs the task specified in ARGV[1]. */
static void
run_task (char **argv)
{
  const char *task = argv[1];

  printf ("Executing '%s':\n", task);
#ifdef USERPROG
  process_wait (process_execute (task));
#else
  run_test (task);
#endif
  printf ("Execution of '%s' complete.\n", task);
}

The initial thread is not created by thread_create()

You may need to add initialisation code for any elements you add to struct thread to thread_init() as well

docs.title: Priority scheduling
docs.text:
requirements: - Rewrite scheduler to take thread priorities into account - Allow processes to modify and query their priority

we always want the ready thread with the highest priority should run

if: - a new thread is created - a thread is unblocked - a thread is woken from timer_sleep

some thread may have higher priority, the current thread should yield to it as soon as possible

sleeping thread should not be woken early, regardless of priority

allow modification to the priority, implement

  • void thread_sets_priority(int new) sets the thread’s priority to new int thread get set priority(int new priority) priority, if valid priority(void) returns the current thread’s (effective) priority

docs.title: Priority donation (for locks)
docs.text:
• Improve performance for high-priority threads

prevent priority inversion by allowing high-priority threads to donate their priority to other threads holding contended resources

priority inversion may occur when some thread of lowerer priority is using the resource, holding the lock while some other thread with higher priority is spawned

  • Multiple threads may donate to a single thread
  • A thread can only donate to one thread (which holds the resource)
  • The donation is revoked when the resource is freed
  • Donations may nest (e.g. A donates to B and B donates to C)

block threads may have their priorities modified

effective priority - A thread's effective priority is always the highest of its base priority and al its Donations

proiority update - THe priority updated by thread_sets_priority(int new_priority) should laways be the thread's base priority

priority query - the priority returned from thread_get_priority(void) should always be the threads's effective priority

docs.title: BSD-style scheduler
docs.text:
• Alternative scheduler implementation based on allocated CPU time
  • Requires implementing some fixed-point maths routines

its another ides of preventing priority inversion using feedback scheduling

  • Measure the CPU usage of each thread every tick
  • Decay the CPU usage for all threads once per second
  • Calculate the system load average once per second
  • Update the priority of threads every 4th tick
  • Always run the thread with highest priority

do not do #ifdefs to disable the scheduler

docs.title: FPU(Floating point unit)
docs.text:
simulate real arithmetic without access to a FPU

Correctness: - Abstract out the actual arithmetic to make the test easier - small differences in implementation (round down / round up, etc,) can have differences in output, read the spec carefully

Effciency: - This code will be run many times a second, being optimal is essential - Functions vs. macros may give different performance characteristics

see section B.6

docs.title: suggested order of the implementation
docs.text:
• choose the best task 0 implementation

  • Initial thread_get_priority() & thread_set_priority()

  • Prioritised unblocking on synchronisation primitives (semaphores,locks and conditions)

  • Priority scheduling

  • Priority donation(suggested hardest)

  • Final thread_get_priority() & thread_set_priority

  • Fixed-point maths routines

  • BSD-style scheduler

docs.title: my task in group: priority scheduling
spec doc:
docs.text:
• When a thread is added to the ready list that has a higher priority than the currently running thread, the current thread should immediately yield the processor to the new thread.
  • Similarly, when threads are waiting for a lock, semaphore, or condition variable, the highest priority waiting thread should be awakened first.
  • In both the priority scheduler and the advanced scheduler you will write later, the running thread should be that with the highest priority.

docs.title: solution?:
docs.text:
we always want the thread with the highest priority to be the first or at a fixed position, a one obvious solution is the sort the list,

sorting the list everything is painful and time-consuming, it will be better if we could init the list sorted, like insertion sort, but we need to take care of conditions that a priority changes

lets first don't care about priority change

if we want the list to be created as a sorted list, we would want to use insert_sort or list_insert_ordered

originally the ready_list or the all_list(the only two lists) is created with list_push_back in thread_yield, init_thread, and thread_unblock

so we change these

watch the params of list_insert_ordered

it take three params, C

void
list_insert_ordered (struct list *list, struct list_elem *elem,
                     list_less_func *less, void *aux)
{
  struct list_elem *e;

  ASSERT (list != NULL);
  ASSERT (elem != NULL);
  ASSERT (less != NULL);

  for (e = list_begin (list); e != list_end (list); e = list_next (e))
    if (less (elem, e, aux))
      break;
  return list_insert (e, elem);
}

then see what is required for less

C
less(elem, e, aux)

following thread_foreach, we can assume the aux is another auxillary variable, possibly not used

the list variable should be &ready_list and the elem should be the list_elem to insert, obviously

the less compares the priority,

we could imagine the less should first get the threads of the two elems by list_entry and get the priority then compare

C
// mycode starts part1

/* 
  compares the priority from list elems
  returns ture if the priority of e1 is less than e2
  the name is for consistency with the list.c functions
  but I don't think we should alter the core lib
*/
bool list_less_priority(struct list_elem * e1,
    struct list_elem *e2, void * aux UNUSED)
{
  struct thread *threadOfE1 = list_entry(e1, struct thread, elem);
  struct thread *threadOfE2 = list_entry(e2, struct thread, elem);
  return (threadOfE1 -> priority) < (threadOfE2 -> priority);
}
// mycode ends

we get

Text Only
../../lib/kernel/list.h:173:27: note: expected ‘_Bool (*)(const struct list_elem *, const struct list_elem *, void *)’ but argument is of type ‘_Bool (*)(struct list_elem *, struct list_elem *, void *)’

so we add two const(const is like java final, the stuff inside the function cannot alter it)

fail, the output was from 30 -> 21, we get the opposite, it should be > in list_less_priority

so I am decieved by the name in list_insert_ordered, the param is less, bu t nonono,

so then we have the first half done

then, when the priority changes, that should be after set_priority

from the previous work, we notice that every time tick, ready_list and all_list is sorted by priority, even if priority change

so all we need to do is block(yield) the current thread, and the scheduler would automatically choose the one with the highest priority

see the comment in the test priority-change

C
/* Verifies that lowering a thread's priority so that it is no
   longer the highest-priority thread in the system causes it to
   yield immediately. */

so we simply add thread_yield to the thread_set_priority

then we get

Text Only
  (priority-change) begin
  (priority-change) Creating a high-priority thread 2.
- (priority-change) Thread 2 now lowering priority.
  (priority-change) Thread 2 should have just lowered its priority.
+ (priority-change) Thread 2 now lowering priority.
  (priority-change) Thread 2 exiting.
  (priority-change) Thread 2 should have just exited.
  (priority-change) end

we check the test

C
void
test_priority_change (void) 
{
  /* This test does not work with the MLFQS. */
  ASSERT (!thread_mlfqs);

  msg ("Creating a high-priority thread 2.");
  thread_create ("thread 2", PRI_DEFAULT + 1, changing_thread, NULL);
  msg ("Thread 2 should have just lowered its priority.");
  thread_set_priority (PRI_DEFAULT - 2);
  msg ("Thread 2 should have just exited.");
}

static void
changing_thread (void *aux UNUSED) 
{
  msg ("Thread 2 now lowering priority.");
  thread_set_priority (PRI_DEFAULT - 1);
  msg ("Thread 2 exiting.");
}

so the thread_create should be executing a bit later

this is because the priority queue may have changed when the thread creates

so we basically just add thread_yield in thread_create

C
tid_t
thread_create (const char *name, int priority,
               thread_func *function, void *aux) 
{
  struct thread *t;
  struct kernel_thread_frame *kf;
  struct switch_entry_frame *ef;
  struct switch_threads_frame *sf;
  tid_t tid;
  enum intr_level old_level;

  ASSERT (function != NULL);

  /* Allocate thread. */
  t = palloc_get_page (PAL_ZERO);
  if (t == NULL)
    return TID_ERROR;

  /* Initialize thread. */
  init_thread (t, name, priority);
  tid = t->tid = allocate_tid ();

  /* Prepare thread for first run by initializing its stack.
     Do this atomically so intermediate values for the 'stack' 
     member cannot be observed. */
  old_level = intr_disable ();

  /* Stack frame for kernel_thread(). */
  kf = alloc_frame (t, sizeof *kf);
  kf->eip = NULL;
  kf->function = function;
  kf->aux = aux;

  /* Stack frame for switch_entry(). */
  ef = alloc_frame (t, sizeof *ef);
  ef->eip = (void (*) (void)) kernel_thread;

  /* Stack frame for switch_threads(). */
  sf = alloc_frame (t, sizeof *sf);
  sf->eip = switch_entry;
  sf->ebp = 0;

  intr_set_level (old_level);

  /* Add to run queue. */
  thread_unblock (t);

// mycode starts task1
  // so basically, there is a possiblity that the priority here is the current highest priority
  // the we need to yield the CPU
  if (thread_get_priority()  < priority) {
    // thread_get_priority gets the priority of the current thread
    thread_yield();
  }
// mycode ends
  return tid;
}

int
thread_get_priority (void)
